clusters.title: Porsche’s insanely clever hybrid engine comes to the 911 Turbo S
clusters.neutral_headline: Porsche’s insanely clever hybrid engine comes to the 911 Turbo S:

items.title: Porsche’s insanely clever hybrid engine comes to the 911 Turbo S
items.standfirst: The new 911 variant is 14 seconds quicker around the Nürburgring Nordschleife.
items.content: Today, Porsche debuted a new 911 variant at the IAA Mobility show in Munich, Germany. It's the most powerful 911 to date, excluding some limited-run models, and may well be the quickest to 60 mph from a standing start, dispatching that dash in just 2.4 seconds. And it's all thanks to one of the most interesting hybrid powertrains on sale today. Rather than just bolting an electric motor to an existing 911, Porsche designed an entirely new 3.6 L flat-six engine, taking the opportunity to ditch the belt drive and move some of the ancillaries, which can instead be powered by the car's 400 V traction battery. The system debuted in the 911 GTS T-Hybrid, which Ars recently reviewed. For that car, Porsche added a single electric turbocharger, which works like the MGU-H in a Formula 1 car. It spins up almost instantly to 120,000 rpm to eliminate throttle lag, but also recaptures excess energy from the spinning turbine and sends that to the 1.9 kWh battery pack.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: Porsche is introducing a new hybrid engine in the 911 Turbo S model.
The new 911 variant is 14 seconds quicker around the Nürburgring Nordschleife.
The article likely details the engine's specifications and performance improvements.

clusters.title: GOP may finally succeed in unrelenting quest to kill two NASA climate satellites
clusters.neutral_headline: GOP may finally succeed in unrelenting quest to kill two NASA climate satellites:

items.title: GOP may finally succeed in unrelenting quest to kill two NASA climate satellites
items.standfirst: One scientist says it's like buying a car and running it into a tree to save on gas money.
items.content: It was in 2002, during the George W. Bush administration, when NASA decided to put a satellite into orbit to track emissions of carbon dioxide, the primary greenhouse gas pumped into the atmosphere through human activity. After many twists and turns, NASA's 23-year remit of charting greenhouse gas emissions could come to a close as soon as the end of this month. President Donald Trump's budget request to Congress calls for terminating 41 of NASA's 124 science missions in development or operations, and another 17 would see their funding zeroed out in the near future. Overall, the proposed budget slashes NASA's spending by 25 percent and cuts NASA's science funding in half. This year's federal budget runs out September 30, and although lawmakers from both parties have signaled they will reject most of Trump's cuts, it's far from certain that Congress will pass a budget for the next fiscal year before the looming deadline. The Trump administration, meanwhile, has directed NASA managers to make plans to close out the missions tagged for cancellation.Read full article Comments

ai_summary: The article discusses the potential for the GOP to halt NASA climate satellites.
One scientist compared the situation to destroying a car to save on gas.
The article likely explores the political motivations behind the move.
